## Your analysis and its story

-   Recording your data analysis story (= the choices you make) is important

-   A story is not easy to extract from code:

    -   Telling a story is not the main purpose of coding languages - the main goal is telling a computer what to do

    -   Not everybody can read code

-   Solution: tell your story together with your code!

## Story + code = notebooks

-   Some examples:

    -   Jupyter

    -   Google colab

    -   Rmarkdown

    -   **Quarto**

-   Text is written in [markdown](https://www.markdownguide.org/) ![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dcurtis/markdown-mark/master/svg/markdown-mark.svg){height="40"}

-   Code is in (executable) code chunks

## Quarto outputs

-   **Documents**: html, pdf and MS word

-   **Presentations**: Revealjs (html), Powerpoint (pptx) and Beamer (pdf/latex)

-   **Websites**

-   **Books**

## Writing quarto

-   Platforms:

    -   VSCode: most used code editor. Works well for rendering python documents.

    -   Rstudio: code editor for R. Works well for rendering R documents.

-   Setup:

    -   Start with a template (Document, Presentation, Website or Book)

    -   Start coding!

## Markdown - lists

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Unordered list

```         
- item 1
    - sub-item 1
    - sum-item 2
        - sub-sub-item 1
```

-   item 1
    -   sub-item 1
    -   sum-item 2
        -   sub-sub-item 1
:::

::: {.column width="\"50%"}
### Ordered list

```         
1. ordered list
2. item 2
    i) sub-item 1
         A.  sub-sub-item 1
```

1.  ordered list
2.  item 2
    i)  sub-item 1
        A.  sub-sub-item 1
:::
:::

## Writing code - chunks

```{r}
#| echo: fenced
library(ggplot2)

mtcars |>
  ggplot(aes(x = drat, y = mpg, color = cyl)) +
  geom_point()
```

## Writing code - chunks

```{r}
#| echo: fenced

head(mtcars[, 1:3]) |> knitr::kable()
```

## Writing code - quarto magic

```{r}
#| echo: fenced
#| label: "fig-mpg-vs-drat"
#| fig-cap: "mpg versus drat"
#| fig-align: "left"
library(ggplot2)
mtcars |>
  ggplot(aes(x = drat, y = mpg)) + geom_point() + theme_bw()
```

```
From @fig-mpg-vs-drat you can see there is a positive correlation. 
```

From @fig-mpg-vs-drat you can see there is a positive correlation.
